paragraph: “From the age of nine to sixteen, I went every Sunday to a  Presbyterian Church, in charge of which, at that time, was a very  cultured minister. In one of the earliest memories which I have  retained of him, I see myself as a very small girl sitting in a very  large pew, continually endeavoring to keep myself awake and pay  attention, without in the least being able to understand what he meant  when he spoke to us of Chaos, Cosmos and the Gift of Love (don  d’amour).”There are also rather early memories of the awakening of puberty (nine to sixteen) which have connected the idea of the cosmos springing from chaos with the “don d’amour.” The medium in which these associations occur is the memory of a certain very much honored ecclesiastic who spoke those dark words. From the same period of time comes the remembrance of that excitement about the idea of the “creative thought” which from itself “produced its object.” Here are two ways of creation intimated: the creative thought, and the mysterious reference to the “don d’amour.”
question:
What significant memories from this period are connected to the idea of the cosmos springing from chaos?

**ANSNWER:**
Significant memories from this period are connected to the idea of the cosmos springing from chaos with the "don d'amour." These memories involve the author's association of the concepts of the cosmos and chaos with the "don d'amour," which was spoken about by a revered ecclesiastic during church services.

**QUESTION:**
How does the author describe the medium in which these associations with the cosmos and chaos occur?
answer: The associations between the cosmos and chaos and the "don d'amour" occur within the memory of a certain very much honored ecclesiastic who spoke about these dark and complex ideas during church services.
